I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
and a proposed grant, both to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the additional financing of 
the Dhaka Environmentally Sustainable Water Supply Project.1 
 
2.  The ongoing Dhaka Environmentally Sustainable Water Supply Project (the ongoing 
project) will provide more reliable and improved security of water supply in Dhaka by developing 
a  new  surface  water  supply  scheme  and  improving  the  existing  distribution  network.  The 
additional financing (the project) will finance the cost overrun of the ongoing project, and a change 
in scope to (i) include a secondary distribution pipeline to ensure the overall outcome of the 
ongoing  project,2 and  (ii)  empowerment  of  women  and  vulnerable  groups  in  low-income 
communities (LICs) and improving their access to basic infrastructure and social services. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Urbanization and water supply issues in Dhaka. The population in Dhaka is growing 
rapidly, and is expected to increase from 20 million in 2018 to 28 million in 2030 at an average 
annual growth rate of 3.0%, exacerbating the challenges in Dhaka’s urban environment.3 Basic 
infrastructure and services, including water supply, are often insufficient. The Dhaka Water Supply 
and Sewerage Authority (DWASA) provides water supply to about 20 million people. It currently 
relies heavily on groundwater, but extraction has been increasing to meet demand, resulting in 
groundwater depletion, with levels declining by 2–3 meters per year.4 Further groundwater 
depletion (with groundwater lowering about 5 meters per year by 2030) will  potentially lead to 
widespread land subsidence, associated higher flood level particularly combined with floods of 
increasing magnitude due to climate change, and severe shortfall in drinking water supply.5 To 
address this, DWASA is increasing its reliance on surface water resource from the current 22% 
to 70%. However, the main existing source of surface water in Dhaka is polluted, and it is 
increasingly difficult to produce water of acceptable quality through treatment; this makes it 
essential for DWASA to find a good quality, sustainable water source. 
 
4.  Support of the Asian Development Bank to the ongoing project. To support DWASA’s 
strategy  (para.  3),  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  concessional  loan  of 
SDR165.0 million ($250 million equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR) for the 
ongoing project on 22 October 2013. The loan closing date is 30 June 2023 following two 
extensions.6 The ongoing project will provide more reliable and improved security of water supply 
in Dhaka, using the Meghna River as a new water source. The river is about 30 kilometers (km) 
east of Dhaka, and has water of good quality and ample quantity even during the dry season. The 
ongoing project supports the development of a water intake, raw water transmission line, a water

treatment  plant  (WTP)  with  500  million  liters  per  day  production  capacity,  treated  water 
transmission line, and primary distribution line. It also improves the existing distribution network 
to reduce nonrevenue water (NRW). Package 1, the largest package (which includes an intake, 
raw water transmission line, and WTP), is cofinanced by (i) Agence Française de Développement 
(AFD) for €47 million ($64 million equivalent), partially administered by ADB; and (ii) the European 
Investment Bank for €100 million ($136 million equivalent), not administered by ADB.  
 
5.  Performance of the ongoing project. The ongoing project is performing well. While it 
experienced startup delays (para. 6), it is now on track with solid progress to meet its outcome. 
Under output 1 (new surface water supply system developed), package 1 is being steadily 
implemented with 40% of design and construction works completed as of 31 July 2021. Package 
2 for treated water transmission line  was awarded in May 2021. Package 3.1 for primary 
distribution line is expected to be awarded in September 2021. Output 2 (distribution network 
strengthened) has been completed in July 2021 except for small packages, and has overachieved 
the 376 km targets for improved distribution networks by about 120 km. Under output 3 (project 
management and administration adequately supported), the project management unit (PMU), the 
two teams of management and supervision consultants, and three nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs) are fully in place.7 As of 31 July 2021, ongoing project cumulative contract awards were 
at 97%, with disbursements at 69%, while time elapsed was 80%. All fiduciary and safeguard 
policy requirements have been met. Management of risks is satisfactory. The current project 
performance  rating  is  ‘on  track.’  The  ongoing  project  is  highly  relevant  in  addressing  the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and future pandemics as it will establish a sustainable and safe 
water supply system which is essential for basic hygiene.  
 
6.  Rationale for additional financing. The ongoing project is experiencing cost overruns. 
Procurement of package 1, using a design-build-operate (DBO) contract, took about 3.5 years 
because of (i) an unfavorable security situation in Dhaka, which led to five extensions of the bid 
submission deadline; (ii) litigation filed by a bidder; (iii) the complexity of evaluating the DBO 
contract; and (iv) lengthy government approval process for this large contract. After the contract 
award in May 2018, the government procedures for land acquisition required an additional year, 
and delays were experienced in the release of cofinancier funds. While these issues were 
subsequently  settled,  the  overall  delays  led  to  a  price  escalation  of  $84.9  million  by  the 
commencement of package 1 in May 2019.8 In addition, because the design by the awarded 
bidder differed technically from the outline design at appraisal, the contract amount of package 1 
was increased by $49.9 million to $329.2 million. During bid evaluation, it was concluded that the 
proposed design was technically more robust and necessary to address liquefaction and river 
erosion risks.9 The land acquisition cost for the overall project also increased by $42.8 million 
because of changes in local law. Lastly, the financiers’ loans depreciated by $45.7 million due to 
currency fluctuation. These factors, together with the associated increase in taxes and duties by 
$78.0 million, consultant cost by $16.2 million, and other items,10 resulted in an aggregate cost 
overrun of $336.0 million in the ongoing project including the government portion. Also, the 
government has requested a new scope of package 3.2, at a cost of $56.2 million, for secondary 
distribution pipeline, as it is essential to achieve the overall project outcome (footnote 2).  
 
7.  Additional financing is a suitable modality as it will ensure continuity of the ongoing works,

3 
and efficiency by using the same implementation and project management arrangements. To 
avoid any further funding shortfall, DWASA and the government will (i) conduct third-party vetting 
of any future variation proposal by the contractors; (ii) strengthen cost containment; and (iii) 
strengthen the PMU, especially on safeguards, to accelerate contractors’ access to sites. The 
overall project (i) remains technically feasible, economically viable, financially sound, and in 
compliance with safeguard covenants; (ii) is accorded high priority by the government (para. 9); 
(iii) retains the same development objectives as the ongoing project and strengthens them with 
the new output 4 ($5.7 million) for gender empowerment (para. 12); and (iv) is consistent with 
ADB’s country partnership strategy (para. 9). The overall project is expected to be completed by 
30 September 2025, within 3 years from the closing date of the ongoing project (30 June 2023). 
 
8.  Lessons. Key lessons from the ongoing project and other ADB-funded projects in urban 
and water sector include (i) a thorough assessment should be made of the capacity of the 
executing agency and the government to evaluate a complex contract modality; (ii) project 
readiness should be as high as possible; (iii) the project implementation period should fully reflect 
the local security situation, and capacity of the executing agency and the government to introduce 
a new contract modality; (iv) to minimize the risk of cost increases, the quality of site investigation 
should be as high as possible, even for DBO contracts;11 and (v) adequate support for capacity 
building is necessary for smooth land acquisition. ADB will continue to document and disseminate 
the lessons learned from this project to inform future projects.  
 
9.   Alignment with strategic priorities. The overall project aligns with the government’s 
Eighth Five Year Plan 2021–2025 which prioritizes meeting  the basic needs of the people amid 
rapid urbanization.12 It also aligns with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Bangladesh, 2021–
2025, that aims to ease urban infrastructure constraints.13 It will contribute to the following ADB 
Strategy 2030 operational priorities (OPs): (i) making cities more livable (OP4) and tackling 
climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental 
sustainability (OP3) by improving water supply in Dhaka through an environmentally sustainable 
scheme;  (ii)  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity  (OP6)  by  strengthening 
DWASA’s  capacity;  (iii)  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality  (OP2)  by  building  basic 
infrastructures with an emphasis on, and empowering women in, LICs; and (iv) addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities (OP1) by providing basic infrastructure in LICs.14  
 
B.  Project Description

sustainable water supply services in Dhaka.15 The overall project will have the following outcome: 
more reliable and improved security of water supply and sanitation in Dhaka.16 The additional 
financing will finance cost overruns and the change in scope under the three outputs of the 
ongoing project, and finance a new output 4. 
 
11.  Outputs 1, 2, and 3. Output 1 (new surface water supply system developed) will develop

a water intake, raw water transmission line, a WTP, treated water transmission line, and primary 
distribution line.17 The additional financing will finance cost overruns under output 1, and a change 
in scope to include secondary distribution line (footnote 2). Output 2 (existing distribution network 
in zone 6 strengthened) will improve the existing distribution network in zone 6 as a continuation 
of DWASA’s efforts toward NRW reduction including new or regularized connections in LICs. The 
additional financing will finance cost overruns under the remaining small packages under output 
2. Output 3 (DWASA’s management and administration capacity improved) remains unchanged.  
 
12.  Output 4: Empowerment of women and vulnerable groups supported. The additional 
Asian Development Fund (ADF) grant financing will be critical in broadening the access of women 
and vulnerable groups in LICs to basic infrastructure and social services, while enabling them to 
act  upon their rights through  sector-focused legal  empowerment  initiatives in line  with the 
Sustainable  Development  Goal  (SDG)  5  transformative  gender  agenda.  It  will  (i)  expand 
DWASA’s gender equity strategy to emphasize women’s equitable rights to clean water and 
sanitation and address this consideration in DWASA’s training modules, tools, and programs;  
(ii) develop socially and gender inclusive emergency response plans for DWASA informed by the 
COVID-19 experience, for dissemination and possible replication across other water utilities in 
Bangladesh and in the region;18 (iii) strengthen women's representation and effective participation 
in governance structures and processes in CBOs to (a) inform financial decisions and budgetary 
allocations for basic infrastructure and social services addressing the needs of women and 
vulnerable  groups;  and  (b)  contribute  to  gradual  institutionalization  of  legal  empowerment 
initiatives (legal literacy and legal aid services) that address, among other issues, the increased 
rate of gender-based violence; and (iv) develop gender-inclusive toilets and bathing facilities in 
selected LICs. The ADF grant will support a range of transformative reforms that would have been 
impossible to support through the loan proceeds for the additional financing that will fund cost 
overruns of the investment project. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
13.  Support for strategic improvement of water supply in Dhaka. Since 2007, ADB has 
been supporting DWASA’s strategic direction to improve water supply services. The completed 
and ongoing ADB-funded projects established district-metered areas and rehabilitated water 
supply networks, contributing to lower NRW and more judicious use of existing water.19 The 
overall project will be mutually complementary to these efforts by connecting the new bulk water 
supply  system  using  surface  water  resources  to  the  improved  network,  thereby  providing 
continuous water supply service to the citizens with sustainable resources.20 ADB has been also 
holistically  supporting  DWASA’s  institutional  strengthening. 21  Further,  ADB  has  provided

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
20.  The water intake, raw water transmission pipeline, and WTP have adopted a DBO contract 
to incentivize design innovation and ensure the integrated design of these facilities and their 
efficient operation.31 The WTP will be compactly built using less land than existing DWASA WTPs 
with fully automated operation for efficient operation and maintenance (O&M). The primary and 
secondary distribution lines will connect the treated water to DWASA’s district-metered areas. 
They  will  be  mutually complementary  to  supply  a  greater  quantity of  sustainable  water  of

increased quality. Climate change assessment and climate risk and vulnerability assessment 
were prepared to assess climate change risks and capture climate change financing. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
21.  Economic analysis. Economic analysis was conducted for the overall project. The 
economic rationale for the government’s intervention is sound, as the project aims to provide 
stronger and more sustainable urban basic services focusing on water supply in Dhaka City. The 
economic internal rate of return of the overall project is estimated at 12.4%, which is higher than 
the economic opportunity cost of capital (EOCC) estimated at 9.0%,32 indicating significant 
economic returns. The results of the sensitivity analysis are also satisfactory against all downside 
risks. In addition, the project is expected to further increase its economic viability if unquantifiable 
benefits such as environmental improvements are included in the analysis.33  
 
22.  Financial analysis. Financial analysis was conducted to assess the financial viability of 
the overall project based on expected project revenues and capital and O&M expenditures.34 The 
financial internal rate of return is estimated at 3.2%, higher than the weighted average cost of 
capital of 1.2%, indicating that the overall project would generate sufficient revenues to cover both 
capital and O&M expenditures. The financial projections for DWASA (carried out for 25 years) 
also indicate that DWASA would have sufficient revenues to cover its O&M costs as well as the 
interest  and  principal  payments  for  its  debts,  except  for  a  brief  period  (FY2024–FY2029). 
Considering that an annual tariff increase of more than 5% requires government approval, 
DWASA needs to enhance its revenue base by (i) further reducing NRW ratio through the ongoing 
ADB-funded Dhaka Water Supply Network Improvement Project (footnote 19); (ii) reducing O&M 
costs through proper asset management and more efficient operation including establishing 
standard  operating  procedures;  and  (iii)  enlisting  continued  government  support,  including 
consolidating  tariff  structure  (being  prepared  under  the  Dhaka  Water  Supply  Network 
Improvement Project). ADB will provide continued policy advice and capacity-building support to 
facilitate DWASA’s financial sustainability.35  
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
23.  The contractor of package 1 will be engaged during the first 3 years of O&M to confirm 
their functionality and transfer O&M skills to DWASA. A draft O&M plan was developed, describing 
standard  operating  procedures  and  budget,  and  will  be  elaborated  during  implementation. 
DWASA’s financial performance is projected to stay strong with its revenue to basically cover both 
the O&M and capital costs (para. 22). It will be further enhanced by the efficiency improvements 
including  assets  automation  and  NRW  reduction.  The  project  will  support  environmental 
sustainability, by switching from ground water to surface water resources. ADB support for 
Meghna River protection is proposed in monitoring the quality of effluent into the river (para. 13).36

(iv) improving asset management practices and systems at the entity level. Moreover, the project 
will maintain separate books of account in accordance with accounting standards acceptable to 
ADB, and the detailed project financial statement will be audited annually by an independent 
auditor in accordance with auditing standards acceptable to ADB. 
 
26.  Procurement. All procurement of goods and works and consultant recruitment under the 
project will adhere to the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the 
Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The DBO 
contract includes 3 years of O&M (para. 23), which enables private sector participation for 
sustainable O&M, and building the skills of DWASA staff. A merit point system will be adopted for 
the evaluation of technical proposals of package 3.2, involving the relatively complex secondary 
distribution line.39 These key aspects in the contracts is expected to contribute to value for money.  
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and DWASA. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 23). Integrity due diligence was conducted.40 Integrity risks 
were identified, arising from adverse media coverage and complaints relating to DWASA’s 
operation and projects. Mitigation measures include continued monitoring by the project team of 
the project from an integrity perspective, increased oversight during procurement, as well as 
strengthened transparency of and publicity regarding DWASA’s projects.41 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
28.  Poverty and social. In Dhaka, people living in LICs generally lack legal access to water 
supply and sanitation, and must depend on illegal water lines or water vendors, and pay higher 
charges.  Under  the  ongoing  project,  community-based  organizations  (CBOs)  have  been 
organized to make LIC residents eligible for legal water connections, either through legalization 
or  new  connections.  The  CBOs  have  been  responsible  for  payment  of  water  tariffs  and 
maintenance of the community water points. Under the ADF grant, community toilets and bathing

29.  Gender. The ADF grant (gender thematic pool) will enable DWASA to deepen and sustain 
the gender impact of its operations, by committing to an enhanced gender equity strategy, in line 
with the transformative gender agenda under SDG 5. An integrated approach to women’s 
empowerment  will  be  pursued  by  (i)  enhancing  the  targets  for  women’s  participation  and 
leadership in decision making, (ii) promoting targeted legal empowerment initiatives for women, 
(iii) engaging men and boys in women’s empowerment, and (iv) supporting women’s greater 
resilience to and preparedness for natural hazards and disasters. This integrated approach to 
women’s empowerment presents prospects for replication in similar utilities and agencies in 
Bangladesh  and  the  region.  More  specifically,  the  ADF  grant  will  (i)  support  DWASA’s 
commitment to (a) women’s increased leadership (up to 40%) in executive bodies of CBOs and 
(b) women’s increased membership (up to 50%) in CBOs; (ii) enable DWASA to act on its 
commitment to sustained access to water supply and sanitation by women and vulnerable groups 
by promoting access to legal empowerment services;43 (iii) engage men and boys to address 
gender  stereotypes  and  discriminatory  practices  including  gender-based  violence,  through 
advocacy and awareness; and (iv) enhance women’s resilience to external shocks by developing 
emergency response plans informed by the gendered impact of COVID-19.  
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
30.  In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  classification  of  the 
additional financing and implementation of the ongoing project is described in paras. 31–34, along 
with the potential safeguard impacts under the additional financing.44 
 
31.  Environmental safeguards (category B). The additional financing is category B for 
environment, based on the assessment that environmental impacts are site-specific, with few if 
any that are irreversible, while mitigation measures are mostly readily available. A draft initial 
environmental examination (IEE) with an environmental management plan was prepared in line 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and government laws. Based on the IEE, no significant 
adverse environmental impacts are envisioned. No project site is located in a sensitive area, and 
any impacts during construction and O&M can be avoided and/or mitigated through measures in 
the  environmental  management  plan.  Further,  an  environmental  assessment  and  review 
framework (EARF) was prepared for components under the ADF grant that will be prepared after 
the ADB Board of Directors approval, for which limited impacts are anticipated. The EARF 
provides site selection criteria to ensure that environmental impacts are not significant. It will also 
guide DWASA in the environmental assessment and preparation of assessment documents for 
this  infrastructure.  The  environmental  assessment  documents  shall  be  submitted  for  ADB 
clearance prior to the start of construction.  
 
32.  The  package  under  the  new  scope  (package  3.2)  will  be  awarded  only  after  the 
corresponding draft IEE is finalized.  Contracts under the  ADF grant will be awarded after 
corresponding assessment reports are finalized based on the EARF. All statutory clearances and 
no objections will be obtained prior to start of construction. Capacity building and training for this

33.  Involuntary  resettlement  (category  B).  The  additional  financing  is  category  B  for

The measures in the draft resettlement plan are adequate to deal with identified risks. The draft

design and submitted to ADB for review. The draft and the updated resettlement plan will be

resettlement framework was prepared for components of the project financed by the ADF grant 
that will be prepared after Board approval. The civil works under the ADF grant are proposed to 
be located on government land, with no acquisition of private land required; possible resettlement 
impacts are therefore anticipated to be limited. The resettlement planning documents shall be 
submitted to ADB for clearance upon finalization of the sites and prior to the start of construction. 
The resettlement framework will guide DWASA in preparing appropriate resettlement planning 
documents. DWASA has demonstrated the capacity to manage resettlement impacts. Project 
consultants  will  further  support  DWASA  in  enhancing  such  capacity.  DWASA  will  prepare 
combined semiannual social monitoring reports for ADB review and disclosure for the ongoing 
loan and additional financing. 
 
34.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project is category C for indigenous peoples in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. No indigenous peoples impacts, involving 
direct or indirect impacts to the dignity, human rights, livelihood systems or territories, or natural 
or cultural resources that are used, owned, occupied, or claimed by indigenous peoples as their 
ancestral domain or asset are anticipated. None of the affected persons surveyed belongs to 
tribes, minor races, ethnic sects, and communities. 2011 census by the Bangladesh Bureau of 
Statistics does not report the presence of any tribes, minor races or ethnic sects and communities 
in the project area including potential area where ADF grant-funded infrastructure will be located.
